page.title: 15Architecture,S'key&C'thorpe.
page.content: {Stiffkey village}part of a Conservation Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty: winding street set in sheltered valley; cottages pan- tiled, dating from 17th., 18th. centuries; some remains earlier e.g.Church, Varied styles of flint and brick. New houses strive to conform. {Idiom:}Flints and Norfolk pamments (thick tiles replacing early blood and offal pounded floors) bedded in mortared chalk or lime mixed with binder e.g.horse-hair or dung. Old ships' timber used in interiors. Bricks dissappeared in Roman times, imported from Holland 17th. century; but bricks and tiles for 16th. century Old Hall made locally (three old clay pits, one called Clavit). {Cockthorpe hamlet:}style similar, set in trees on hill-top at edge of bleak war-time airfield.
